This mission, besides successfully testing the LSAM in its full configuration of 4 astronauts as it was meant to be, would also offer a better Earthrise photo compared to the Apollo 8 mission. This mission will be essential in paving way for longer-duration lunar landing missions using the LSAM and in the future the Space Shuttle.

1976:

The Equal Rights Amendment officially becomes the 24th amendment to the constitution of the United States of America, which would guarantee legal rights for all American citizens regardless of sex and end distinctions between men and women in matters of divorce, property, employment etc. This came after the state of Illinois became the 39th state in the country to officially approve the ERA, 3 years before the deadline. This becomes an important political issue and represents a significant stepping stone when it comes to the rights of women in America, this would be celebrated by rockefeller republicans (including Lodge) and also liberal democrats.

The 1976 elections are also wild, as the Equal Rights Amendment, stagflation, the future of space travel, the energy crisis and even things like America's foreign policy were important issues. In the Republican primaries, incumbent president Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. would just narrowly manage to beat Ronald Reagan, a member of the party's right-wing conservative faction, 53% to 47% and winning only 40 delegates more than Reagan, which showed the party's ever-growing division. Meanwhile the Democratic Party would rally behind a 44-yr old Ted Kennedy, who was seen as a bright visionary and hopeful candidate in these desperate times, easily winning out with 57% of the vote against Jerry Brown, Henry Jackson, George Wallace and Jimmy Carter among others and also because Kennedy would be portrayed in a better light compared to today. George Wallace, discontent with the fact that both party candidates were liberals would run a third party Dixiecrat campaign. The presidential elections would result in the victory of Democrat Ted Kennedy with 310 electoral votes, the incumbent president would get 194 electoral votes while George Wallace and the Dixiecrat Party would get 34 electoral votes. Ted Kennedy's VP would be Birch Bayh, Henry Cabot Lodge's VP would be the current Nelson Rockefeller and George Wallace's VP would be Lester Maddox. He would be the first president to be a biological young brother of a previous president in American history.

The first shuttle mission (STS-1) is done, where the Space Shuttle Enterprise (the spaceplane), equipped with the first stage based on kerolox (RP-1/LOX) powered by 5 F-1 engines and with the second stage (also known as the external tank), powered by 3 RS-25 engines (strapped onto the spaceplane, not the tank, but the second stage fuel tank based on hydrolox - LH2/LOX is the fuel source) and the space shuttle would have its own OMS engines based on hypergolic propellant. The mission, uncrewed this time and not with astronauts, would send the shuttle into low-earth orbit and then have it land at a shuttle runway built near Cape Canaveral. The first stage (the RP-1/LOX stage) would also actually land itself at a Cape Canaveral landing pad using the RCS thrusters and 3 parachutes so that it wouldn't expend as much rocket fuel (only expending around 150,000 lbs of fuel instead of 500,000 lbs) and the second stage which deployed its 3 parachutes and would have used RCS thrusters to slow it down and then a helicopter would grab it and send it back to KSC.

The computer company, Apple, is founded by Steve Jobs and Steve Wozniak, these people also being part of a growing movement seeking to privatize Arpanet and give this advanced government technology to the private sector where it could allow for all sorts of things. In the same year they create the Apple I computer, the company's first such computer. The American Bicentennial celebration also commences on the 4th of July of 1976, or 200 years after the declaration of independence of America from the British Empire.

The Soviet Union would send Zvezda 20 and 21 to the Salyut space station and would even land cosmonaut Yuri Glazkov to the surface of the Moon with the LK lunar lander, launched on an N1 rocket. They would also send the Venera 11 mission to the surface and orbit of the planet Venus. Meanwhile, a devastating death would happen, Sergei Korolev, chief rocket engineer of Roscosmos and the Soviet Union would die in 1976, at the age of 73. While he said he wanted to appoint Vasily Mikhin as his successor, he would serve for a short period before Vladimir Chelomey, the creator of the Proton-K and Energia rockets would become the next Roscosmos top dog, which may mean a completely new direction from that of Korolev.

In the United States, Skylab 9 and Skylab 10 would happen in the year 1976, these being missions to the Skylab space station, although these may soon be replaced by Space Shuttle missions, which may offer limitless potential due to its fully reusable properties, offering low-earth orbit (to Skylab), moon orbit and moon surface missions for astronauts. Meanwhile, Apollo 27 would see the return of humans to the Moon with the LSAM launched on a Saturn V, it only containing a 2-astronaut LSAM configuration. Astronauts Jack Lousma (commander) and Steven Nagel (pilot) for the first time since Apollo 25 in 1974.

1977:

Ted Kennedy is officially sworn in as the 38th president of the United States and promises to fix the inflation crisis, to bring about great progress and to begin a new era of economic growth and American prosperity, tapping into the narrative of the cut-short wonder that his older brother John F. Kennedy would have brought when he was president, but was assassinated. In his first month of office, he appoints Paul Volcker, governor of the New York Federal Reserve as chairman of the Federal Reserve (across the entire USA) in order to deal with the crisis of inflation.

The deadliest accident in aviation history occurs as a Pan-American Airlines Boeing 747 collides into a KLM plane at Tenerife airport, killing 583 people, this would become known as the Tenerife disaster. South Vietnam's Nguyen Van Thieu decides to invade Cambodia, led by Pol Pot after a short-lasted cold war between the two, immediately toppling him alongside anti-Pol Pot resistance forces and the support of countries like Thailand and North Vietnam, soon enough, the Khmer Republic would be re-established with instead a president, Saukam Khoy, choosing not to bring back the unpopular dictatorship, although there would still be guerrila resistance for quite some time.

In this year, there are around 5 Shuttle missions, STS-2 on February 7th of 1977, STS-3 and STS-4 on August 20th, 1977, the first also being part of Skylab 11 and would send a new pair of astronauts, Richard Truly, Norman Thagard and Ellison Onizuka (the first Asian-American astronaut) to the Skylab space station. This would also see the testing of the fully-finished Manned Maneuvering Unit (MMU), first on the ground and then as part of a tethered spacewalk. STS-3 and STS-4 would be an unmanned mission and would launch the Voyager 1 and 2 probes, with the first set to make flybys of Jupiter and Saturn and the second set to make flybys of Uranus and Neptune before using them as gravity assists to go far out, beyond the solar system. The Voyager probes are also special not just that they're meant to study and offer great footage of the gas giants, but are also meant to be a message to the cosmos, just like the Pioneer 10 and 11 probes. STS-2 would be a Shuttle Enterprise mission and it would land at Edwards Air Force, STS-3 would be a Shuttle Columbia mission, STS-4 would be another Columbia mission.

STS-5 would launch astronauts Judith Resnik, James van Hoften (the first two who would land on the Moon using the LSAM), James Buchli and Steven Hawley (who would stay in the Space Shuttle) in lunar orbit as part of Apollo 28, landing on the Moon for the second time using the LSAM and also landing at Faustini crater. STS-6 would send another lunar reconnaissance orbiter made to be bigger and also a modified design of the Apollo Command & Service Module (CSM) and would also send cubesats to Moon orbit and low-earth orbit. STS-5 would be a Shuttle Enterprise mission and STS-6 would be a Shuttle Discovery mission. This year would also see two missions of the Space Shuttle Vanguard, owned by the USAF, one launched from Vanderberg Air Force Base and another from Cape Canaveral Air Force Base, but would both land at the Vanderberg runway, the first one carrying a military spy satellite and the other the first global positioning system (GPS) satellite, the Block I version. Launch costs have fallen significantly thanks to this Space Shuttle, instead of costing 10,000-15,000$/kg every launch, it costs just 1,000$/kg, a 90% reduction, while for the military shuttle (Vanguard) it is 2,500$/kg, due to its configuration not being fully reusable (only partial) and also the more expensive nature of miliary missions. t

The Soviet Union would for the first time launch the Buran spaceplane on the 5th of September 1977, mounting it on the Energia rocket and would send it to low-earth orbit, carrying two cosmonauts Igor Volk and Anatoly Levchenko as part of Zvezda 22 mission to the Salyut 6 space station, which was launched on a Proton-K rocket after the previous had re-entered just a few months prior, sadly making an Energia-boosting impossible. The Soviets would also successfully demonstrate the landing of their spaceplane, the Buran, autonomously.

Paul Volcker, the new chairman of the Federal Reserve, would begin raising interest rates to a record 15%, resulting in a reduction in inflation from 12% at the beginning of the year to just 5% by the end of it, although the economy would be at a slow down due to high interest rates, although the economic outlook would begin to improve as the inflation would begin to decline and thus the interest rates.

In this year, Ted Kennedy would manage to get a landmark universal healthcare bill, the Affordable Care Act (ACA), which would implement for the first time actual healthcare in the USA, implementing mandatory private health insurance with a public government option, allowing 15% of the U.S. population, which previously did not have insurance, would now have access to it, fixing a fundamental problem within the healthcare system. He would also implement an amendment to the Clean air act that would expand the cap and trade system to other harmful substances like carbon dioxide (CO2), nitrogen dioxide (NO2) among other substances which are emitted and will also have more regulatory power given to the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), with narrow victories in Congress.

1978:

A civil war erupts in Afghanistan as local resistance in the form of the National Resistance Front (NRF), also known as the Mujahideen, rise up against the Soviet-backed communist government of Afghanistan, the Mujahideen being a group of islamist fighters willing to end Soviet, atheist control over their own country. Evsei Liberman, unlike Leonid Brezhnev of our own timeline, chooses not to invade the country, which leaves the Afghani civil war raging on for decades afterwards to the present day as there is no Soviet and American backing of any side, thus neither can break the stalemate.

There would be an additional 6 STS missions in 1978, the first one, STS-7, on February 12th, 1978 which had astronauts Bruce McCandless, Sally Ride, Ronald McNair and Robert Stewart would have Bruce McCandless conduct the first untethered spacewalk, going as far as 100 meters from the Space Shuttle Pioneer, using the Manned Maneuvering Unit (MMU). STS-8 through 10 would also be low-earth orbit missions, while STS-11 would be a Type "I" mission meant for Shuttle lunar reconnaissance and extended orbital stays before returning to Earth, it also seeing the first spacewalk in lunar orbit by astronaut Robert Springer on the 8th of September 1978. STS-12 would see the first launch of Space Shuttle Victoria and it would be as part of a satellite repair mission on the 27th of September of 1978 and would carry astronauts Roberta Bondar (from Canada), Norman Thagard, Ronald Grabe and Loren Shriver to low-earth orbit.

The Soviet Union launches as part of Zvezda 23 cosmonauts Aleksei Gubarev and Vladimir Remek (from Czechoslovakia) as part of the first mission of the Interkosmos program of the Soviet Union, this program includes the USSR + the Warsaw pact countries but also other Soviet-aligned nations such as Mongolia, Vietnam, Cuba, Afghanistan, Syria and India. Zvezda 24 which would also happen this year, it carrying cosmonauts Pyotr Klimuk and Miroslaw Hermaszewksi (from Poland), the second mission of Interkosmos and all launched to the Salyut 6 space station on an Energia-Buran rocket. This also forces the United States to respond with its own multinational program known as Cosmos, which would include Canada, Japan, ESA-member states (West Germany, France, Spain, Italy, United Kingdom and Switzerland) but also South Korea, Australia and New Zealand, this opening a new frontier space travel as it offered small countries the chance to explore space themselves, even if through the means of the Soviet and American space giants.

1979:

The Soviet Ministry of Communication changes the name of OGAS to Sovnet, giving it the same naming style as America's Arpanet. This also comes after some computing power improvements to the system. Evsei Liberman also willingly signs into law the creation of the Soviet version of the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA), the one that America has and the agency it, America, uses for its powerful internet system, which is used by government science foundations, the military etc. it being an interconnected link all under the government, while the people have a less advanced version of it from private companies, same thing in the Soviet Union, although their personal computers (from private companies) are worse due to the scarce number of them.

In this year, a group of businessman and scientists, mostly in the technology sector, such as Microsoft CEO Bill Gates and Paul Allen, Apple CEO Steve Jobs and Steve Wozniak, CERN scientist Tim Berners-Lee (and also the inventor of URL and HTTP, a decade or so earlier than in OTL), Oracle CEO Larry Ellison, Adobe CEO John Warnock, among others, have sent a letter to both United States President Ted Kennedy and Soviet President Evsei Liberman seeking the creation of a World Wide Web (WWW) that knows no borders and goes beyond their self-imposed Iron Curtain and also the privatization of Arpanet, giving it to the hands of private individuals and companies which they say will allow for a revolution in communication, technology, science and will even see a great political upheaval which shall be the new bearer of the next millenium, a better world for us all. However, their proposals (for now) are ignored. This letter officially saw the addition into the vernacular of the populace of "internet rights activist."

There would be a record 14 shuttle (STS) missions this year, going from STS-12 to STS-26, 5 of them being Space Shuttle Victoria missions, 2 of them being Space Shuttle Kon-Tiki missions, 2 of them being Space Shuttle Enterprise missions, 2 of them being Space Shuttle Columbia missions, 1 of them being a Space Shuttle Discovery mission and another being a Space Shuttle Atlantis mission, the last two being the first of its kind and they would happen from a span of February-November 1979, including STS-18, which would see Shuttle Kon-Tiki refuel the Skylab space station, preventing its deorbiting and allowing for future missions on it. STS missions 14, 15, 20, 21 and 23 would all be missions to the Moon, with STS missions 20 and 21 actually landing astronauts on the surface as part of Apollo 29 and Apollo 30 both at Shackleton crater. STS mission 23 would carry the Viper rover to the Moon, it having the goal of collecting samples of helium-3 and water-ice from the lunar south pole. The other missions would be to the Skylab space station, reaching Skylab 22 to it.

The military (U.S. Air Force) would also have another slew of missions as part of STS-22B, STS-31C and STS-24D, the first two sending spy satellites to low-earth orbit and the other sending another GPS satellite and this would be done using the Space Shuttle Vanguard. STS-31C would be launched from Vanderberg, while the rest would be launched from Cape Canaveral.

Ted Kennedy successfully negotiates with the Shah of Iran, Mohammed Reza Pahlavi to create a constitutional monarchy with a dominant-party system in politics, in the country while in return he would get more U.S. money for building up his country economically, for the secret police, for maintaining secularism and for the military and other things. The Iran Revolution would wound up being in fact just a small protest done by radical islamists and would paint them in an even worse picture as they commited violence to get their way. Aytollah Khomeini would be locked up for life instead of killed, as to prevent his martyrdom and riling up of other Iranian islamists, this preserves the Pahlavi Dynasty and also allows for more stability in the Middle East and in the world as the whole drama of the crisis does not happen. The Soviet Union, under Evsei Liberman, denounces this meddling and in response begins arming Iraq for a potential invasion of Iran.

A nuclear meltdown is successfully averted at the Three Mile Island, as such in this timeline the anti-nuclear movement never gains popularity and nuclear is still viewed relatively positively. While yes the fact that Arpanet is more advanced in this timeline than in our own allowed for this, it still meant that the plant and other need service extensions and as such it was undertaken. In this timeline, as of 1979, nuclear makes up around 40% of energy production in the USA and clean energy sources overall have reached around 55%, surpassing fossil fuels for the first time. The previous years and this would begin to see significant reductions in the emissions of greenhouse gasses, like carbon dioxide, although there is a growing problem when it comes to CFCs and the ozone layer as environmental activists continue to raise the alarm about them. Ted Kennedy is working on an international agreement to phase out emissions of these CFCs, but it isn't coming to fruition yet.

1979 would be a year of high economic growth, the U.S. economy growing by 5%, as the previous two saw slow increases after the end of the stagflation period and also . Prices across the board are beginning to decline as inflation is down to usual levels of 2-3% instead of high levels like 10% or 12%. The Iranian Revolution not happening also means that there isn't a second oil price shock. Japan would also become a country as its private companies are beginning to catch up to American ones, as they have companies like Toyota, LG, Sony etc. which is raising alarms. It became the 3rd country to hit the mark of 1T$, as the USA has 3T$ and the USSR has 2T$, it surpassing the countries of West Germany, the UK and France, who are all at 700-800B$. Some are beginning to say that the century beginning in 2001 will be known as the Japanese century.

Roscosmos would have 3 Buran missions in 1979, one of them, Buran 3, would land cosmonauts Vladimir Kovalyonok and Alexei Leonov, and it would be the first landing of a spaceplane on the surface of another celestial body, also being intertwined with Soyuz 5. Meanwhile, Buran 2 and Buran 4 would be missions to the now Salyut 7 space station as part of Zvezda 25 and Zvezda 26 and Interkosmos 3 and 4. In this year, there would also be a Zvezda 27 mission but launched on a Soyuz rocket on the Soyuz crew capsule, it only carrying Romanian cosmonaut Dumitru Prunariu to Salyut 7 and . An Energia rocket would also launch a deep space mission, collecting an asteroid sample from near-earth asteroid 99942 Apophis and would later send this Vega probe as part of Vega 1 (Zond 7) on an impact course to asteroid 1855 Korolyov, named after the deceased Soviet rocket engineer Sergei Korolev, who died in 1976. The Buran would carry not only the probe but also an upper stage for the probe meant to get it to the mentioned aster
